review_title: Great work place for doing a PhD
pros: Great colleagues, nice city, good sources of additional optional funding
cons: Graz is not the biggest city (but certainly cozy)

review_title: Good work-life balance, great opportunity to learn
pros: In the beginning of a PhD candidate job, there is not so much pressure for results while learning and adapting to the job role is on focus. Afterwards, from the time you will start producing results, a great freedom is given as well as a great responsibility.
cons: You have to be self-motivated and deadline responsible on your research. As research is done, sometimes there is luck of time management and decisions making.

pros: Flexible time (home office is possible) Working with industry and academia is possible
cons: Career development is limited No advance payment and bonus

pros: Great location, good research community, solid salary
cons: i don't have anything negative to say

pros: interesting topics, flexible working times, little administration, good interactions with colleagues
cons: some working utilities are outdated

pros: good institute to work in excellent community
cons: slow moving management structure and organization

review_title: great working conditions, benefits, annual leave days, and work-life balance
pros: Stimulating and international environment great working conditions, 25 annul leave days per year plus several special leave, great work life balance being Graz a city with both international presence, cultural offer, and exchange, and access to nature and outdoor sports. Great working mentality, focused on productivity (and the need to take some time off as well, once your working hours are over) rather than working long hours in a stressed and unproductive way. In line with Austrian standards, annual Mitarbeitergeschprach are held to promote a happy and healthy working environment, and happiness of employees.
cons: I see no real cons, if not that while English is absolutely enough when working at university, learning German language becomes necessary to be able to better integrate and fully enjoy the opportunities outside university.

pros: Good work-life balance, mostly not stressful
cons: No room for advancement in career Very low salary compared to the industry

review_title: Great place to get paid for learning what you like and get your Ph.D.
pros: You'll get a higher salary compared to almost anywhere else doing a Ph.D.
cons: Quite a demanding environment, no work-life balance for a Ph.D. student. Quite unfair treatment between those who keep things running and researchers that do the minimum if any!

pros:
- Great place to continue & grow your scientific career!
- Research Focused,
- Nice In-House Career Development Program,
- Work-Life Balance.
cons: -	Might get lost when it comes to legal matter

pros: Flexible working culture and friendly colleague. International welcome center support department is really helpful!
cons: Did not find big research project that are really interesting for me. Might be different to other people depends on their interest.

pros: Lots of support and wide range of subjects to work on, super open to give anyone a chance.
cons: I mostly had pandemic issues which would not apply everytime

review_title: Good if you are native Austrian
job_title: Full Stack Web Developer in Graz
pros: Stable working environment, nice perks
cons: Hard to get good salary or promotion as a foreigner.

pros: If you want to do research then its a nice environment.
cons: Its a smaller city then competing universities.

pros:
Good life work balance
Good research
cons: Very limited carrier advancement opportunities

pros: flexible hours, relaxed atmosphere, work with students
cons: the organisation in general , poor project leading, non-expert mentor

pros: Good Science, nice people (depends on your department though)
cons: You have to go after two consecutive contracts or maximum 6 years if you have no permanent position but that´s Austrian Law not the fault of TU Graz

pros: work on things that help with your own studies

review_title: Relaxing, stimulating place to work at
pros: Good colleagues and work environment, stimulating workplace and access to cutting edge research.
cons: Can't think of any, maybe the pay could be better?

pros: Salary, Diversity, Research , Luxury, Fun
cons: no cons , or I quit this survey this is my last try. idiots

pros: It is very good place.

pros:
- Great team
- Research is encouraged

cons: - Lacks structure, in some cases

a nice student town
research is industry-oriented
employers are correct

it is a small town with limited industry/academic posibilities 
salary is small

pros: Great university, flexible working hours possible
cons: Complicated accounting of business traveling

pros: The purpose of this position is to pursue a PhD. The Institute for Computer Graphics and Vision is a great research institute, which is performs top leading research.
cons: This is not a permanent position, the continuation of the contract always depends on the availability of ongoing projects.

review_title: It might really be worth a try do your PhD elsewhere instead
job_title: Wissenschaftlicher Mitarbeiter und Universitätsassistent in Graz
pros:
Great freedom to pursue self-chosen research projects/topics.
Still acceptable payment (for public research in computer science). Flexible Working hours.
cons:
Often advice by older research staff(beyond post doc level)  is sparse and not really related/relevant to own research problems - or even distracting from the important aspects. Professors seem oblivious to the real research problems at hand and are most of the time occupied with their (important but never ending) hunt for funding or just traveling around another conference (without actually presenting publications there).

New Research staff does not get proper support - I'm glad that I started my PhD elsewhere so I was able to start a lot more efficiently than how I see things develop for younger PhD students here at the TU Graz.

It is sometimes embarrassing to assist in teaching while being fully aware that a lecture is outdated in many spots, the corresponding practical exercise is lacking in didactics or overly focused with interchangeable / arbitrary technical details.  But to improve the situation one would have to sacrifice too much of one's time for research.  

Abundance of bureaucratic regulations - not just for PhD Students. Information on regulations is scattered over many places. Administrative staff often seems unmotivated and provides contradicting advice on bureaucratic regulations.

Ridiculously low funding to attend international conferences - If you are not a professor yet, that is.

review_title: PhD studies at Graz University of Technology
pros:
- Good Computer Science Department
- Comparably good salary for a PhD position
- Teaching opportunities as a university assistant
- International success possible when working hard
cons:
- Public school, anyone can study; not always highly motivated students
- Not enough Professors or senior researchers per student
- Research funds highly depend on the Professor, little direct government funding
- Sometimes competitive environment even within institutes
- Not a campus university as in the US

review_title: It is an university of technology with a few successful departments.
pros: nice city, good infrastructure, nice offices
cons: hardly any career opportunities; a lot of unnecessary bureaucratic overhead from HR etc., hardly any cooperation with other Unis in Graz (no funds = no support!)

pros:
- nice and young working environment
- appropriate salary as assistent researcher
- great gain of knowledge
- possibilities to research freely in many areas
- not very bureaucratic
cons:
- limited support by supervisors
- you have to find your own funding
- no daily benefit/allowance for international trips
- limited possibilites for carrer development

pros: A lot to learn, the atmosphere can be great but obviously depends on your department and team so can be generalised
cons: Pay is low, long hours, lots of commitment, as far as I can remember only 1/3 of PhDs get it done in 5 years. Most people need 6 years.

pros: Nice place to work. Similar to other PHD programs the payment is not exciting, but enough to make it through.
cons: There are famous universities (like ETH Zurüch, Cambridge, US universities) which make it easier to get recruited for a Post-Doc.

pros: Well established roles, awesome community,  technology is everywhere around, coffee and meal breaks. Ability to work from home at a last minute notice.
cons:
Could have been cleaner.
Departments do not work well with each other which really hurts the entire operation

review_title: disappointing in terms of career options
pros: mainly free to research what you want
cons: no overtime compensation, without 80 h a week the job is not possible

+ no fixed working hours (flexibility)
cons:
